intro: Mosla leucantha, commonly known as white woodruff, is a perennial herb native to the temperate regions of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate leaves that have a slightly hairy surface. Its small, white or pale blue flowers are clustered in whorls along the stems, blooming in early summer. Mosla leucantha is often used in traditional medicine and as a ornamental plant due to its fragrant foliage and delicate appearance.
